Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>Looks good...of course there is always a question of how long you
>should let a species stagnate before purging it (the dropoff_age
>  
>
I opted for 100 generations simply because I know that a search with a 
population of 150 will run fast enough to see several hundred 
generations - and therefore I will see the species culling in action. Of 
course if we leave a species for longer it might still improve later so 
I guess it comes down to how long you want to leave your search running 
for, if you are going to leave it for days then you can afford a higher 
dropoff_age.

Another way viewing species culling is as a method of walking the search 
space. When we cull a species we are giving up on a local maxima that 
has been found and moving on to another point (or points) in the problem 
space,  a higher droppoff_age allows NEAT to make a more thorough search 
of the problem space around the species before we give up on it and move on.

>parameter in my version of NEAT).  Also, if the population size chages
>that's definitely a major problem that needs to be fixed.  It probably
>indicates something wrong with the way offspring are being assigned.  
>Anyway, looks like you already fixed it.
>  
>
The underlying maths was OK, I use the alternative method for 
determining the species size as described in the faq -  
((AverageSpeciesFitness / TotalOfAllSpeciesAverageFitness) * 
baselinePopulationSize).

Once this number was calculated I called the CreateOffspring_Asexual() 
and CreateOffspring_Sexual() routines the relevant number of times - the 
problem was that the sexual reproduction function tries a maximum of 3 
times to find a mating pair and then gives up - and I wasn't 
compensating for these failed attempts at generating offspring. Now if 
sexual repro fails I call the asexual offspring routine as a last resort.

I think that this defect was a major hindrance for searches since 
CreateOffspring_Sexual() was most likely to fail with a new species 
with, say, one or two good genomes in it, thus causing a selection 
pressure against good genomes!

Anyway I reverted to the original (pseudo-)randomized prey capture 
trials, but now with deterministic starting positions and prey initial 
moves, one run obtained a 92/100 score on the most difficult test within 
50,000 evals - which is really impressive. To perfect the results 
further I'm now going to try and award a higher fitness for networks 
that can catch the prey in as few timesteps as possible, this hopefully 
will guide the search towards finding prey that chase the prey rather 
than using mechanical strategies. This is something that begins to creep 
in with more difficult trials where the prey is allowed to move and 
where I therefore have to allow the agent many more timesteps than may 
be strictly necessary. You see the prey movement is unpredictable so it 
may take 10 moves or 20 to catch it even with a perfect strategy, so I 
have to assume the worst case and give the agent at least 20 moves. The 
trouble is that if the prey did some stupid moves then the agent should 
have caught the prey within 10 moves, but it gets the same fitness if it 
used up all 20 moves to carry out a mechanical strategy.

Colin.
